neighbors.name: Milligan Energy Center LLC
neighbors.claims: Milligan Energy Center LLC is a project entity formed by Ørsted for a planned 315 MW solar farm with a 315 MW/1,260 MWh battery system on land in Eloy, Pinal County. The project is described as a long-term asset that will provide clean power to ~68,000 homes and help meet Arizona’s energy needs. Ørsted projects that the facility will generate millions in local tax revenue and create around 300 construction jobs, reflecting significant economic benefits for the Eloy area. Arizona Public Service has even planned a new 230 kV line and substation (named “Milligan”) to connect this project, indicating institutional support for integrating the solar center into the grid.
neighbors.influence_justification: Backed by a global energy firm ($1 billion+ investment, 2000+ acre site); provides tax base and jobs but is a newcomer to the community

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Ørsted’s development manager directly; explore collaboration or land agreements that align their project with yours, highlighting mutual benefits and avoiding conflicts in grid interconnection

neighbors.name: Eloy 170 LLC
neighbors.claims: Eloy 170 LLC is an Arizona limited-liability company that holds land in the Eloy area and has been selling portions for commercial use. On June 12, 2025, Eloy 170 LLC sold a 33.43-acre parcel at Milligan Road and Sunshine Blvd. to Blue Beacon, Inc. (a truck wash operator) for $375,348, signaling a strategy of flipping land to interested buyers. The company assembled multiple adjacent parcels (total acreage likely over 100 acres) near the I-10 corridor, indicating a speculative land investment with no publicly known operating business. The actual members or owners of Eloy 170 LLC are not disclosed in public records, so its ultimate ownership and decision-makers remain unknown.
neighbors.influence_justification: Primarily a speculative landholder; not a major employer or community institution, minimal public or political profile

approach_recommendations.engage: Contact the LLC’s representative or agent discretely; propose win-win terms (e.g. premium purchase or benefit to their other parcels) to secure their support or neutrality for the development

neighbors.name: Arizona Public Service Company
neighbors.claims: Arizona Public Service Company (APS) is the state’s largest electric utility and has acquired land in this vicinity for planned grid infrastructure (a new substation and transmission line to support incoming generation). APS exerts a major economic impact as Arizona’s top taxpayer, contributing roughly $11.3 billion annually to the state’s economy. The utility has publicly emphasized the need for more solar farms and battery storage in Pinal County to meet a projected 40% surge in power demand, reflecting a generally supportive stance toward new energy developments in the area. APS’s expansion plans in Pinal (including the “Milligan” 230 kV line) suggest it is actively facilitating renewable projects and stands to benefit from improved grid reliability and capacity.
neighbors.influence_justification: Largest electric utility in region; significant taxpayer and employer; deep political and regulatory influence on local development

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with APS’s government affairs and transmission planning teams early; align the project’s benefits with APS’s grid needs and policy goals to secure their buy-in and support

overview_summary: The adjacent landowners include a large renewable energy developer, a speculative land investment LLC, and Arizona’s primary electric utility. Ørsted’s Milligan Energy Center (315 MW solar + storage) signals corporate-backed support for new energy projects and promises significant local tax revenue and jobs. Eloy 170 LLC appears to be a land speculator flipping parcels for profit, not an active community stakeholder. Arizona Public Service (APS) is a dominant regional utility that is generally supportive of new power developments to meet soaring demand and wields substantial political and economic influence in Pinal County.
